multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 depicts the charge modulation (δρc) and spin alternation (δρs) as functions of the ionicity parameter (Δ) for varying hopping parameter ratios (t↓/t↑). What happens to the charge modulation (δρc) as Δ approaches infinity?
choices: δρc approaches 0 for all values of t↓/t↑.
δρc approaches 1 for all values of t↓/t↑.
δρc approaches 0 for t↓/t↑ = 0 and 1 for all other values of t↓/t↑.
δρc approaches 1 for t↓/t↑ = 0 and 0 for all other values of t↓/t↑.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 illustrates the order parameters and gap parameters for the mass-imbalanced ionic Hubbard chain for a potential strength Δ = 6 and different hopping anisotropies. What is observed for the gap parameters (Δ↑, Δ↓) as the on-site interaction (U) increases beyond the transition point (Uc)?
choices: Both Δ↑ and Δ↓ become negative.
Both Δ↑ and Δ↓ remain positive.
Δ↑ becomes negative while Δ↓ remains positive.
Δ↓ becomes negative while Δ↑ remains positive.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 displays the mean-field phase diagrams for the mass-imbalanced ionic Hubbard chain in the U-Δ and U-t↓ planes. Which statement correctly describes the phase boundary between the ionic (I) and antiferromagnetic (AF) phases?
choices: The phase boundary is strongly dependent on the hopping imbalance (t↓/t↑), particularly for low values of U.
The phase boundary is almost independent of the hopping imbalance (t↓/t↑), especially for high values of U.
The transition from the I to the AF phase is always of second-order.
For large values of Δ, there is a single second-order phase transition between the I and AF phases.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (35) provides an estimation for the critical interaction strength (Uc) for large values of the ionic potential (Δ). What does this formula predict for the relationship between Uc and Δ as Δ approaches infinity?
choices: The relationship between Uc and Δ cannot be determined from this formula.
